title: What's the least bullshit job you've had?
description:
Flip side to https://lobste.rs/s/3omsld/ever_had_bullshit_job , because I was starting to feel a little depressed‚Ä¶ what jobs have you had that you felt were genuinely enjoyable, useful and productive?

For me that‚Äôs actually my current job writing software for cargo drones. I think it‚Äôs one of those technologies that genuinely will change the world, mostly for the better, and it‚Äôs super exciting to be in it from the ground up. I‚Äôm going to quit in a few months because hoo it‚Äôs a lot of work and I‚Äôm a bit burned out‚Ä¶ but there‚Äôs a 50% chance I‚Äôll come back after a season or two and say ‚Äúhey, turns out everything else in the world is less cool, want me back?‚Äù
description_plain:
Flip side to https://lobste.rs/s/3omsld/ever_had_bullshit_job , because I was starting to feel a little depressed...  what jobs have you had that you felt were genuinely enjoyable, useful and productive?  

For me that's actually my current job writing software for cargo drones.  I think it's one of those technologies that genuinely will change the world, mostly for the better, and it's super exciting to be in it from the ground up.  I'm going to quit in a few months because hoo it's a lot of work and I'm a bit burned out... but there's a 50% chance I'll come back after a season or two and say "hey, turns out everything else in the world is less cool, want me back?"

title: Ever had a bullshit job?
description:
I‚Äôm reading this book: Bullshit jobs, and supposedly, the world is rife with people who answer yes to one of these questions:

  • a) Although you are required to do your job, you secretly believe it is pointless and should not need to be performed.
  • b) Although you are required to do your job, you secretly believe it is pointless and does not contribute to the world.

One poll found 37% answered yes to a question like that.

I‚Äôve never had a job that was total BS but I did have days as an Eng Manager where I felt like I attended meetings and received information and then attended other meetings and disseminated it. I was acting as a node in a complicated corporate phone tree.

Another example, a QA found bugs and verified bugs that would never be prioritized and fixed. Another might be someone who is propping up some bloated code that they could fix, but for Kafkaesque reasons, that‚Äôs not the job

So have you ever had a bs job? What was it like?
description_plain:
I'm reading this book: [Bullshit jobs](https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/34466958-bullshit-jobs), and supposedly, the world is rife with people who answer yes to one of these questions:

* a) Although you are required to do your job, you secretly believe it is pointless and should not need to be performed.
* b) Although you are required to do your job, you secretly believe it is pointless and does not contribute to the world.

One poll found 37% answered yes to a question like that. 

I‚Äôve never had a job that was total BS but I did have days as an Eng Manager where I felt like I attended meetings and received information and then attended other meetings and disseminated it. I was acting as a node in a complicated corporate phone tree.

Another example, a QA found bugs and verified bugs that would never be prioritized and fixed. Another might be someone who is propping up some bloated code that they could fix, but for Kafkaesque reasons, that‚Äôs not the job

So have you ever had a bs job? What was it like?
